WRITING.TEXT: Thanks, I appreciate the kind words.
Thank you
Thank you very much. What you described is generally what I saw in the scene, so I'm glad to have conveyed it to a decent degree.

WRITING.TITLE: Bennet Valley Road, Oil on Board, 14" x 11"

WRITING.TEXT: Yes, pretty much. There is a slight hint of it, but it's really just in the shadow. Glad you like the other aspects of the piece :)

WRITING.TITLE: Nude in Blue, Oil on Canvas, 20" x 30"
Alice Keck Gardens, Oil on Masonite, 16" x 12"

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you!

WRITING.TITLE: Water Silo, Oil on Masonite, 16" x 12"

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you. It is not based on a photograph. I painted it on location at a friend's farm where they had this old truck just sitting there.
Thank you, and thank the sun :)

WRITING.TITLE: Green Truck, Oil on Canvas Board, 10" x 8"
Betsy's Barn, Oil on Canvas Board, 14" x 11"

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you!
Oddly enough, I am from NYC originally and I had to look this reference up. The more you know.

WRITING.TITLE: Picante Sauce, Oil on Masonite, "8" x 10"

WRITING.TEXT: Thank you. I actually made a blog post about the process [HERE](http://aritargownik.blogspot.com/2011/12/still-life-made-using-form-modeling.html) . I haven't really used this blog in a long time, this painting is almost 6 years old.

Thanks. I went to school at Pratt Institute, but I wouldn't say I learned to paint in this manner from my time there. This specific painting came from following a method I found on the blog of [Douglas Flynt](http://douglasflynt.blogspot.com/search?updated-max=2010-06-13T14:12:00-07:00 max-results=7 start=17 by-date=false) . Although I can't find the specific entry he talks about it, here is my post on the process of it: [my old blog](http://aritargownik.blogspot.com/2011/12/still-life-made-using-form-modeling.html)

Yes, I am. I'm pleased you like it, thank you for the kind words :)
Feel free to check out more of my stuff on my website: http://www.aritopia.com/Fineart.html
Or my Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/aritargownik/
Yes
That's definitely something! Thanks.
Thanks :D
Thanks :)

WRITING.TITLE: Lined Up, Oil on Canvas, 24" x 12"

WRITING.TEXT: Of course there are cards in general, but in the vein of what they described in the announcement?

Maybe I don't know enough history wise, but only a couple of these seem what I would call "Iconic". I just really don't get how they are going to manage making this set justify the pack price without breaking the reserved list. I am curious to see what it all ends up like.
Dat Richard Kane-Ferguson tho

This did occur to me, and I agree with you. Still, my knee jerk reaction with regards to reading the card title, then looking at the image, was that the Alpha version summed it up best/cleanest. This seems to be the trend for the older art vs the newer art in general - such as in the example of Fling.
This was the sort of tug of war I went through with Giant Spider. The alpha version is the most blatantly obvious "GIANT spider", but not necessarily the best art piece of the bunch.
Bill Nye, Seance guy
Low curve is one way to go about it, but it's power increases with larger creatures to give haste to. It REALLY would be amazing if it had cycling.
It's amazing on turn 1, the rest of the time...less so.
It would make the inclusion of Prowling Serpopard kind of sad/pointless though.
Almost as many keywords as [[Chromanticore]]
Correct. That's what I meant by "as creatures". So, just the stats and key words.
[[Enigma Sphinx]] is pretty bad ass looking, made by the same artist.
Or [[Sphinx of the Final Word]]
You kind of see the ult in [[Kiora, Master of Depths]] . The focus of a planeswalker card is always the planeswalker, so any abilities they do have to take a back seat, visually.
I know "In a vacuum" is kind of a silly/useless term, but, in said vacuum I think 4/6 Menace is, aside from Kefnet, the best of all the Gods as creatures.
As somebody else commented, playing creatures is what you want to be doing anyway (unless you are playing control). Also, there are cards that produce tokens, not committing much there.
Double Strike totally caught me off guard - this is not a pun.

WRITING.TITLE: What card on the Reserved List would be fair in Standard and viable (but not broken) in Modern?
WRITING.TEXT:
There may be several, but which would be the best candidate?
Reserved List: http://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/official-reprint-policy-2010-03-10

I'm not gonna say the things you pointed out are incorrect, but none of these things were glaringly off enough to distract me from what is going on in the picture. My first reaction was, "man, that's messed up" (what is happening to the drowned guy), then I saw Gideon and his reaction. Basically, it tells a story well and the colors are nice too. I didn't think about any of the stuff you mentioned, that's just me though.
